body:
Have you tried changing the colors in `alacritty.yml`\[[1]]?  The defaults there may not be ideal.

[1]: https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty#configuration
\[[1]]: https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty#configuration

> Have you tried changing the colors in alacritty.yml[1]? The defaults there may not be ideal.

Ah yes, I know about configuration and took a look at the implementation in `ansi.rs`. I suspect that the problem here is that `Gray` and `Darkgray` are not supported, but I'm not 100% sure about that. More digging is definitely required.

Here are Alacritty's supported colors:

``` yaml
  # Normal colors
  normal:
    black:   '0x000000'
    red:     '0xd54e53'
    green:   '0xb9ca4a'
    yellow:  '0xe6c547'
    blue:    '0x7aa6da'
    magenta: '0xc397d8'
    cyan:    '0x70c0ba'
    white:   '0x424242'
```
Reading a little more from [here](http://bluesock.org/~willg/dev/ansi.html), I think I know how to fix this. I'll try to get a patch together pretty soon.

I believe that what is missing is the ability to configure the 6 colors that come after the first 16 colors (colors 17 to 21 from the 256 palette). Some programs use them and (erroneously?) assume them to be shades of gray. In the 256 palette they are defined as shades of blue so they need to be overridable for them to look good..

@malakin You can configure those colors, but not through the Alacritty config file. For example,

```bash
printf "\x1b]4;%d;rgb:%2.2x/%2.2x/%2.2x\x1b\\" 10 255 255 255
```

would set the color index 10 to ffffff.
@jwilm Yes. I guess that would be the way to do it without cluttering `alacritty.yml` with non standard stuff.

Alright, I dug into this one a little more today, and admittedly, the problem seems to have mostly been my misunderstanding of how ANSI colors work in terminals (although it's not exactly intuitive). Some [canonical references refer to ANSI color codes](http://misc.flogisoft.com/bash/tip_colors_and_formatting) this way: * Code 37 as "light gray" * Code 90 as "dark gray" * Code 91 through 96 as "light" colors * Code 97 as white Alacritty uses a more traditional approach which I think derives from [an old standard called "aixterm"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ANSI_escape_code#Colors) (but I'm not sure; more reading required here): * Code 37 is white * Codes 90 through 97 are "bright" colors * Code 90 is "bright black". * Code 97 is "bright white" I'm not sure where the light versus bright conflation comes from, but these seem to be treated as roughly the same thing, and it probably doesn't matter which adjective you use as long as they're different from the normal color set. What's interesting is that even terminals that are using the same nomenclature as Alacritty tend to be informally respecting the first system when it comes to the light gray/dark gray/white/black; maybe because the concepts of "bright black" and "bright white" are nonsense. iTerm2's color palette does a good job of demonstrating this: As you can see in the screenshot: * Normal black = black. * Bright black = dark gray. * Normal white = light gray. * Bright white = white. @jwilm Would you be open to trying a similar scheme by modifying Alacritty's default color scheme? From what I gather, it seems to be expected at least informally in places, and seems to make UIs that use grays more readable. Here's what my proposed patch would be: ``` patch diff --git a/alacritty.yml b/alacritty.yml index b6ad6a3..5dbf48c 100644 --- a/alacritty.yml +++ b/alacritty.yml @@ -93,18 +93,18 @@ colors: blue: '0x7aa6da' magenta: '0xc397d8' cyan: '0x70c0ba' - white: '0x424242' + white: '0xc7c7c7' # also serves as "light gray" # Bright colors bright: - black: '0x666666' + black: '0x686868' # also serves as "dark gray" red: '0xff3334' green: '0x9ec400' yellow: '0xe7c547' blue: '0x7aa6da' magenta: '0xb77ee0' cyan: '0x54ced6' - white: '0x2a2a2a' + white: '0xffffff' # Visual Bell # diff --git a/alacritty_macos.yml b/alacritty_macos.yml index 0c16d42..4aa656d 100644 --- a/alacritty_macos.yml +++ b/alacritty_macos.yml @@ -92,18 +92,18 @@ colors: blue: '0x7aa6da' magenta: '0xc397d8' cyan: '0x70c0ba' - white: '0x424242' + white: '0xc7c7c7' # also serves as "light gray" # Bright colors bright: - black: '0x666666' + black: '0x686868' # also serves as "dark gray" red: '0xff3334' green: '0x9ec400' yellow: '0xe7c547' blue: '0x7aa6da' magenta: '0xb77ee0' cyan: '0x54ced6' - white: '0x2a2a2a' + white: '0xffffff' # Visual Bell # ``` And here's a screenshot of Mutt under Alacritty looking much more readable with the new colors:
After reading @brandur's patch, it appears the current defaults for normal white `0x424242` and bright white `0x2a2a2a` are backwards, as `0x424242` is brighter than `0x2a2a2a`.

> After reading @brandur's patch, it appears the current defaults for normal white 0x424242 and bright white 0x2a2a2a are backwards, as 0x424242 is brighter than 0x2a2a2a.

Yeah, just flipping the two colors might be an adequate fix in itself.

Swapping won't be enough, IMHO.  Assigning `0x424242` as bright white is still darker than dark gray which is currently `0x666666`.  Your patch has merit since it puts the color values in proper order for black, dark gray, normal white, and bright white.

> Assigning 0x424242 as bright white is still darker than dark gray which is currently 0x666666. Your patch has merit since it puts the color values in proper order for black, dark gray, normal white, and bright white.

Ah, I was thinking more if you flipped the current values of "normal white" and "bright black", you'd get to:

    black    < bright black < white    < bright white
    0x000000 < 0x424242     < 0x666666 < 0x2a2a2a

... which is at least the right order of progression.

I agree though that it would be nice to stick to the proposed patch. Both `0x424242` and `0x666666` are dark colors, and not tremendously useful against a black background.

@brandur definitely happy to update the default color scheme. The iTerm version of this color scheme (Tomorrow Night Bright) has white and bright white as `ffffff`. Other than that, I don't think other changes are needed.

issue.title: Treat white and bright black as grays
issue.body:
See #503 for background, but this starts treating white as a light gray
and bright black as a light gray. This is a commonly found idiom and
makes programs that use gray more readable.

I took the new prooposed colors from the default iTerm2 color scheme.

Fixes #503.

body:
> @brandur definitely happy to update the default color scheme. The iTerm version of this color scheme (Tomorrow Night Bright) has white and bright white as ffffff. Other than that, I don't think other changes are needed.

Cool, thanks! I opened a PR with some colors from iTerm2's default color scheme over in #536. We can talk about particular colors over there.
